children: Palliative medicine is a medical specialty that seeks to relieve suffering and maximize quality of life for patients with a serious illness. It utilizes an interdisciplinary team care model, with a focus on reducing pain and other physical, emotional, psychological, and spiritual symptoms associated with advanced disease.
All physicians practice some degree of palliative medicine and should learn and use basic palliative medicine skills in patient care

. Specialty palliative medicine teams coordinate with referring physicians to align care with the patient's goals, preferences, and values and address multidimensional care needs. Evidence shows that specialty palliative medicine improves overall quality of life, physical symptom burden, mood, and caregiver satisfaction with patient care in the setting of serious illness. Notably, a palliative medicine team does not replace the primary physician, hospitalist, or specialist; rather, the team acts as an extra layer of support, integrating key information from the referring physician into goal-concordant care plans and attending to symptoms that affect quality of life. It remains the responsibility of the primary physician to explore psychosocial distress, provide anticipatory guidance, and perform basic symptom management before or concurrent with referral to palliative medicine specialists.

Although referral to palliative care historically occurred at the end of life, an emerging consensus of research indicates that early initiation during a serious illness is associated with substantial advantages. Evidence on the benefits of subspecialty palliative care has mostly involved patients with incurable cancer. However, numerous guidelines highlight the need for early palliative care in patients with advanced cardiac, pulmonary, or kidney disease; advanced dementia; critical illness; or cancers with potentially curative interventions.
Specialty palliative medicine improves overall quality of life, physical symptom burden, mood, and caregiver satisfaction with patient care in the setting of serious illness.

title.__html: Communicating With Patients With Serious Illness

children: Communicating With Patients With Serious Illness

For patients with serious illness, there are considerable disparities between the care they report they want and the care they receive. Patients report a strong desire to have conversations focused on illness progression and prognosis, expected symptoms and symptom course, and end-of-life issues, and they wish to have these conversations with the clinician whom they view as their primary physician contact. Timely and skillful communication with patients, family members, and caregivers is essential to align care with patients' wishes. However, many physicians report that they do not have the training for conversations about end-of-life care, and many conversations occur too late, are of poor quality, and happen outside of the primary physician-patient relationship. Even among clinicians caring for populations for which consistent advance care and end-of-life planning are considered usual care, it may be unclear when end-of-life discussions should take place and who should facilitate them.
Structured conversations are associated with improved goal-concordant care and reduced patient anxiety. One model for skilled communication with patients facing a serious illness is outlined in

The Serious Illness Conversation Guide provides sample phrases that are designed to elicit a patient's goals, preferences, and values after the patient's illness understanding is assessed. In contrast to discussion techniques in which information is shared and subsequently patients are asked to choose from a list of medical interventions, the Serious Illness Conversation Guide encourages shared decision making and enables physicians to help patients understand the illness and prognosis, elicit important goals, and make recommendations for care. The output of these conversations should be communicated to the patient's family, surrogate decision maker, and other appropriate members of the health care team. Institutional advance directives, commercial advance directive forms or electronic applications, physician orders for life-sustaining treatment (POLST) paradigm forms, and medical orders for life-sustaining treatment (MOLST) forms should be viewed as mechanisms to record the outcomes of these discussions rather than as conversation guides. For further discussion of advance care planning and advance directives, see

Patients report a strong desire to have conversations focused on illness progression and prognosis, expected symptoms and symptom course, and end-of-life issues, and they wish to have these conversations with the clinician whom they view as their primary physician contact.
Structured conversations about serious illness are associated with improved goal-concordant care and reduced patient anxiety.

Effective, proactive symptom management is critical to the success of both basic and specialty palliative care interventions. Management of debilitating and distressing symptoms can markedly improve a patient's functioning, sense of hope, and overall quality of life. For a discussion of pain management at the end of life, see

Dyspnea is a prominent and distressing symptom in patients with advanced illness. The initial goal of treatment is to address the underlying cause (e.g., pleural effusion, infection, anemia, COPD, heart failure) and treat hypoxemia (oxygen saturation ≤90% breathing room air), if present, with supplemental oxygen. A trial of high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy may be considered for patients who have significant dyspnea and hypoxemia despite standard supplemental oxygen. A trial of noninvasive ventilation therapy also may be offered to patients without contraindications who have significant dyspnea despite standard measures. Many patients with advanced illness have persistent dyspnea despite maximal medical management, and opioids, most commonly morphine, are the treatment of choice in these patients. Opioids reduce the sensation of dyspnea and do not cause respiratory depression or hasten death when appropriately selected and dosed. Patients with dyspnea-related anxiety who continue to have dyspnea despite opioid therapy may benefit from short-acting benzodiazepines. There is mixed evidence regarding the benefit of nonpharmacologic interventions in relieving dyspnea. Mindfulness practices, relaxation, acupuncture, or chest wall vibration may be reasonable in selected patients. Patients with a life expectancy of days who continue to have refractory dyspnea despite all standard and palliative treatment options should be offered continuous palliative sedation. See

Audible oropharyngeal secretions at the end of life (“death rattle”) are often distressing for families and clinicians alike and may occur in up to 50% of dying patients. These secretions are thought to rarely affect respiratory status or cause patient discomfort, although the actual effect on the patient is unknown. Educating family members on the dying process can ease concerns. Treatment is often initiated in anticipation of or response to family distress. Measures such as repositioning the patient and withdrawal of parenteral hydration may be helpful. Compared with placebo, prophylactic subcutaneous scopolamine butylbromide reduces the occurrence of death rattle without clear evidence of an increase in adverse effects, but may prolong the dying phase by a few hours. Deep suctioning by catheter should be avoided unless secretions are causing obvious respiratory distress. Nonpharmacologic interventions, such as raising the head of the bed or positioning the patient on his or her side, may be helpful.

Nausea and vomiting are common and debilitating symptoms in patients with serious illness, with many patients rating nausea as more distressing than unrelieved pain. Management of nausea should be tailored to address the underlying mechanism and associated neurotransmitter pathway

. More than one agent is frequently required for symptom relief. In hospitalized patients, parenteral agents should be administered on a scheduled basis to achieve symptom control and reduce the number of emesis events. Nausea prophylaxis in patients receiving chemotherapy is discussed in more detail in

Constipation is common in patients with serious illness and can result in extreme discomfort, restlessness, and delirium. Causes include opioids, dehydration, immobility, metabolic disturbances, and numerous nonopioid medications. Prophylaxis should be considered when constipation is likely to occur, such as with opioid initiation or when prolonged immobility is anticipated. Patients with constipation should be educated on increasing fluid intake and physical activity as much as possible. Pharmacologic therapy includes osmotic laxatives, such as polyethylene glycol, often in combination with a stimulant laxative, such as senna or bisacodyl. Docusate, alone or in combination, is no more effective than placebo for constipation in patients with serious illness. Third-line therapy consists of rectal suppositories and/or enema preparations. Phosphate- or magnesium-containing enema preparations are contraindicated in patients with serious illness, owing to the potential for dangerous electrolyte shifts. Treatment strategies for opioid-induced constipation are covered in

Anorexia and weight loss frequently occur as part of the natural progression of life-limiting illness. Management involves addressing any reversible contributors to anorexia to ease patient and family distress. Although some medications are marketed for patients with anorexia and weight loss, they are marginally effective in a minority of terminally ill patients and often have unacceptable side effects. Enteral or parenteral artificial nutritional support at the end of life does not improve survival; is invasive; and can cause side effects, including increased respiratory secretions and uncomfortable edema. Discussing common end-of-life symptoms, including anorexia and weight loss, and the lack of clearly effective treatments for these expected changes can prepare patients and their family members and set realistic expectations.

Although symptoms of anticipatory grief are common at the end of life, clinical depression is not experienced by most patients and should not be expected. Clinical depression worsens quality of life and, if present, should be treated aggressively. In contrast to neurovegetative symptoms that accompany terminal illness (e.g., poor appetite, low energy), symptoms of unrelenting helplessness, hopelessness, and lack of pleasure should raise concerns for depression.

Depression in terminally ill patients responds well to both pharmacologic and nonpharmacologic treatments, including psychotherapy. Pharmacotherapy consists of antidepressant agents that are appropriate for the patient's estimated prognosis. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors are effective and safe in patients with end-organ dysfunction; however, their therapeutic effects may not be reached for several weeks. In patients with an estimated life expectancy of less than 6 weeks, psychostimulants, such as methylphenidate, are favored.

Anxiety is a common symptom in patients receiving palliative care, often coexisting with depression. Potential triggers include existential fears, the uncertainty inherent to the dying process, difficult decisions, concern for loved ones, and financial issues. Some treatments, including hormone therapy, may also induce anxiety.

Management includes nonpharmacologic means, including social support, relaxation therapy, exercise, mindfulness meditation, and psychotherapy. Pharmacologic treatment with benzodiazepines may be appropriate, although close monitoring for adverse events, including delirium, is necessary. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors can be helpful in patients with coexisting depression and anxiety.

Delirium at the end of life has many potentially reversible causes (medication side effects, inadequate analgesia, pain, urinary retention, constipation), although a cause is often not identified. Treatment of reversible conditions and nonpharmacologic interventions, such as maintaining hydration, providing orienting stimuli, and reducing noise, remain standard care; however, for some patients, medications may be required to maintain patient and caregiver safety and to ensure relief from suffering. There is little evidence, however, that antipsychotics are effective for this indication or that first-generation antipsychotics, such as haloperidol, are inferior to newer-generation antipsychotics. The combination of benzodiazepines and antipsychotics may be more effective than antipsychotics alone in the treatment of delirium at the end of life.
Opioids are the pharmacologic treatment of choice for dyspnea in patients with advanced illness; when appropriately selected and dosed, opioids do not cause respiratory depression or hasten death.
Pharmacologic therapy for constipation includes osmotic laxatives, such as polyethylene glycol, often in combination with a stimulant laxative, such as senna or bisacodyl.

Enteral or parenteral artificial nutritional support at the end of life does not improve survival; is invasive; and can cause side effects, such as increased respiratory secretions and uncomfortable edema.

Clinical depression should not be expected in patients at the end of life and should be aggressively treated if present; pharmacotherapy consists of antidepressant agents that are appropriate for the patient's estimated prognosis.

Hospice is a form of palliative medicine that provides specialized interdisciplinary care to patients with life-limiting illness for whom disease-directed treatments are no longer effective or desired. Hospice care is appropriate for patients with a life expectancy of 6 months or less, if the disease takes its natural course.

Hospice can be provided in multiple settings, including the home, skilled nursing facilities, and residential hospice homes. Hospice team members include physicians, advance practice clinicians, nurses, social workers, pharmacists, chaplains, and other providers whose goals are to maximize quality of life for patients with advanced or terminal illness who are no longer receiving life-prolonging treatment. Hospice teams are associated with improved overall satisfaction with care for patients and caregivers.

Hospice referral should be considered for all patients with a limited life expectancy and is not restricted to those at the very end of life. In addition, hospice is not limited to patients with cancer; patients with a wide variety of underlying conditions receive benefit. Unfortunately, despite proven patient and caregiver benefits, hospice referrals often occur too late in the disease process, denying patients comprehensive, quality care at the end of life.

Ferrell BR, Temel JS, Temin S, et al. Integration of palliative care into standard oncology care: American Society of Clinical Oncology clinical practice guideline update. J Clin Oncol. 2017;35:96-112.

Hui D, Bohlke K, Bao T, Campbell TC, Coyne PJ, Currow DC, Gupta A, Leiser AL, Mori M, Nava S, Reinke LF, Roeland EJ, Seigel C, Walsh D, Campbell ML. Management of Dyspnea in Advanced Cancer: ASCO Guideline. J Clin Oncol. 2021 Apr 20;39(12):1389-1411.
Kavalieratos D, Corbelli J, Zhang D, et al. Association between palliative care and patient and caregiver outcomes: a systematic review and meta-analysis. JAMA. 2016;316:2104-14.
Lakin JR, Block SD, Billings JA, et al. Improving communication about serious illness in primary care: a review. JAMA Intern Med. 2016;176:1380-7.
Nikooie R, Neufeld KJ, Oh ES, et al. Antipsychotics for treating delirium in hospitalized adults: a systematic review.
Swetz KM, Kamal AH. Palliative care.

van Esch HJ, van Zuylen L, Geijteman ECT, et al. Effect of Prophylactic Subcutaneous Scopolamine Butylbromide on Death Rattle in Patients at the End of Life: The SILENCE Randomized Clinical Trial. JAMA. 2021;326:1268-1276.

title.__html: Representative Skill Sets for Primary and Specialty Palliative Care

children: Representative Skill Sets for Primary and Specialty Palliative Care
Basic management of pain and symptoms
Basic management of depression and anxiety
Management of refractory pain or other symptoms
Management of more complex depression, anxiety, grief, and existential distress
Assistance with conflict resolution regarding goals or methods of treatment
Assistance in addressing cases of medically inappropriate interventions at the end of life

footnotes: Reproduced with permission from Quill TE, Abernethy AP. Generalist plus specialist palliative care—creating a more sustainable model. N Engl J Med. 2013;368:1174.

children: “I'm hoping we can talk about where things are with your illness and where they might be going. Is this okay?”
2. Assess illness understanding and information preferences
“What is your understanding now of where you are with your illness?”
“How much information about what is likely to be ahead with your illness would you like from me?”
Prognosis: “I'm worried that time may be short.”
“This may be as strong as you feel.”
“What are your most important goals if your health situation worsens?”
“What are your biggest fears and worries about the future with your health?”
“What gives you strength as you think about the future with your illness?”
“What abilities are so critical to your life that you can't imagine living without them?”
“If you become sicker, how much are you willing to go through for the possibility of gaining more time?”
“How much does your family know about your priorities and wishes?”
“It sounds like ______ is very important to you.”
“Given your goals and priorities and what we know about your illness at this stage, I recommend….”
Affirm your commitment to the patient

title.__html: Treatment of Nausea in the Palliative Care Patient

children: Treatment of Nausea in the Palliative Care Patient
Gut wall stretching or dilatation (constipation, bowel obstruction, ileus)
Gut mucosal injury (radiation, chemotherapy, infection, inflammation, direct tumor invasion)
receptors, and neurokinin type 1 receptors in the chemoreceptor trigger zone
Antidopaminergic antiemetics, glucocorticoids, serotonin antagonists, and neurokinin-1 receptor blockers (aprepitant, netupitant)
) receptors and muscarinic acetylcholine receptors in the vestibular system
